author: daaabears1
body: There are so many companies that offer greater growth than Ericsson. The components that Ericsson makes are high cost and low margin. On top of that they have to compete to get contracts. The downside to this is that the number of contracts can be sporadic and unreliable. To my knowledge there isn’t much, if any, advantage to choosing Ericsson versus Nokia components. Further, BofA recently came out with their 14 moonshot technologies report that said 5G will be the shortest cellular generation before we move into 6G. Also, the S&P has risen 26% in the last year (98% in last 5 years) and Ericsson has risen 3.9% in the past year (54% in last 5 years) so it’s significantly trailing the market. If you are dead set on 5G, I’d suggest looking in $FIVG because they own holdings that have performed greater than Ericsson. Take a look at $FIVG holdings like apple, google, or semi companies like $AVGO, $QCOM.

author: merc123
body:
Glad I avoided WATT at $8 around their IPO. 

I believed in it when Apple thought about using them 5 years ago for OTA charging.  They had a grand idea of whole house charging. You walk in and your phone automatically starts charging anywhere in your house (within distance of the charging station - like WiFi). FCC and Apple squashed that idea when they didn’t approve it and Apple went with Broadcom Qi. 

Even with this approval I’m not so sure. There are a lot of physics hurdles that it would face. You would need a lot of these devices to cover a house or multiple devices to cover even a room in a standard US home. Also distance plays a big factor - longer = less charging power to the point it may not even be relevant.  WiFi has less of these hurdles obviously. 

Throwing a couple hundred at it as a speculative stock may be worthwhile.

author: yopladas
body:
You could look at non-Chinese companies with revenue expose in China. 

For example, electronics used to make smartphones and PCs are made using parts from Qualcomm (CPU), Micron Technologies (flash memory), Broadcom, Veeco, AMD, TI (semiconductors). There is less exposure (<=25%) at NVidia, Intel, Apple, CAT, Ford, GM, Starbucks, Nike, and Apple all have some exposure but not a huge amount, which is good. 

You can search for more companies using Tijori Finance's website, for example have a look at Apple here: https://tijorifinance.com/us/company/AAPL/overview

author: DoDaOpposite
body:
Why not just hold XLK if you want that much exposure to mega tech stocks?  And since you "know" those companies will go up long term, dont bother reading below.  I only post it for others that may not be so.... arrogant.

"Among the largest 15 companies in the index ( they are talking NASDAQ ) back in 2000, only four remain in the top 15 today: Microsoft, Cisco, Intel and Qualcomm.

Over the entire 781-week period, only Qualcomm and Microsoft stocks had   
positive returns -- up 1.54% and 1.34% annually, respectively. Cisco's   
stock had a cumulative return of -52.5% (-4.8% annually) and Intel was   
down 24.63% (-1.9% annually)."

author: InnocentAnthro
body:
Tesla is supply constrained - meanwhile other companies in the market have *spare* or *convertible capacity.* This will be an issue in keeping market share. 

Besides, you're missing my point. It doesn't matter whether Tesla had a bright future, I never denied that they have effective tech, an effective product and solid manufacturing potential. Tesla isn't going to collapse as a business. However, you can have great companies which are massively over-valued (think Cisco in dot-com era) and Tesla is one of these companies.

Tesla's current valuation doesn't make sense. In terms of EVs, VW is just a few % points behind Tesla in global market share (and has an equally bright future in this market) but is valued at 1/6 the value **despite having extensive market share in ICE markets**. That is absurd, Tesla made $31.5bn in revenue in 2020 whereas VW made $258bn in 2020. Fundamentally, the current valuation of Tesla is wrong. That's the problem with Tesla.

author: ScreamingBuy1962
body:
Make it slow and steady instead of trying to make a fortune overnight.  I am 59 and when I was in my twenties I was paying off student loans while putting what was left in options trading.  I made what felt like a small fortune in Csco options before I lost big. 

I stopped trading options in 1995 and starting gradually building up a stock portfolio.  When the IPhone came out I was I intrigued about the new  Apple. When I was at an awards dinner I saw my first sergeant watching a live basketball game on his iPhone—holy cow!  I bought 400 shares the next day, I think it was trading around 40 bucks a share in early 2007. That $16,000 appl investment is worth $2.25m today.   Own it don’t trade as Jim Crammer would say.
